CHAPTER 1
INTRODUCTION
In this chapter, we describe the research background with respect to hand kinematics analysis methods and state-of-art studies of hand and fingers tracking system, then we show the significance of researches for hand and fingers tracking technology in various fields (section 1.1). Next we state our research motivation (section 1.2), and we present overall contribution and innovations of the research (section 1.3). We finish up with the basic organization of the following of the thesis (section 1.4).
1.1 Research Background and Significance
Recent researches have focused on developing hand and high-precision finger motion detection systems for a variety of applications based on tracking methods, such as robotics, virtual reality, and medicine Rehabilitation. Some of those applications are as follow:
-Robotics:  The most popular study field in robotics is the manufacture of prostherix hands. Researchers design prototype of an underactuated prosthetic hand, which improve the range of motion and dexterity of thumb and pinch and innovatively restore the capability of the thumb-index pinch [1].
-Virtual reality:  Hand movement is the main means of interacting with the environment, so it is crucial in virtual reality (VR) applications. Although the existing inverse kinematics motion detection is sufficient for full body tracking (Fig.1.1) [2], it is difficult to locate small body parts such as fingers, and these parts are often blocked in the optical detection process. VR professionals need additional systems (such as inertial trackers) with low reliability [3].
-Medicine Rehabilitation:  A 5-DOF hand rehabilitation robot is designed and developed using a synthetic method for generating natural curved finger tip motion using a 1-DOF mechanism (Fig.1.2). It’s practical in the diagnosis and treatment of hand injuries and diseases [4].
With the help of advanced sensors and computer vision methods, those system is able to capture and analyze finger movements. Machine learning algorithms are often used to interpret the data and provide real-time feedback to users [5,6] .
These studies give us examples and inspires of the importance of hand-finger motion detection in different industries, and also show promise in improving the accuracy of the finger motion detection and tracking system. However, there are still challenges in developing a compact and comfortable system for users to wear and use for a long time, as well as its applicability in more application scenarios.
1.2 Motivation
The existing research has done enough detail in measuring and tracking hand movements, and has derived many extensions and applications in various fields. However, the bending and extension of a single finger is different from the movement of the entire hand, and the detection of finger movement becomes very difficult when moving or rotating.
In current finger motion detection technology, there are two distinct categories can be distinguished depending on the use of cameras or individual sensors. 
-Vision based: Use passive optical motion capture technology by setting cameras to capture the dynamic image of a specially designed glove with markers, then use the machine vision technique to process the images and correlate the local variation of image to the motion of fingers or change in the hand gesture [7,8]. The vision based hand tracking system has non-contact perception function, making hand motion detection convenient and efficient. Besides, machine vision and imaging analysis based on camara involve expensive components and complex algorithms [9], which are very expensive for ordinary users.
The main advantage of a vision based system is its high tracking accuracy, but it has drawbacks such as sensitivity to light intensity fluctuations and occlusion issues, which may lead to tracking errors [10].
-Sensors based: The sensor-based systems directly detect the motion and bending of the fingers using various types of sensors such as accelerometers [4], gyroscopes, magnetic sensors, resistive sensors, and ElectroMyoGraphy (EMG) sensors [11] etc. To a certain it can help to mitigate the problem of vision-based system. Besides, the sensor-based systems are also in general more compact and inexpensive. However, acceleration or inertial sensors are generally susceptible to gravitational artifacts due to the rotation and vibration of arms or bodies.
In our research, we intend to design and develop a magnetic sensors based device which is hihgly compact and have ability to detect finger motions real-time accurately. Because magnetic sensors have advantages over limitations of vision based systems which severely restricted the adoption of hand tracking in real-world applications (bulky tethered systems is impractical and line of sight or privacy concerns) [12].
Finger tips are significant marks of hand kinematics analysis, which have fewer amounts than joint angles of fingers and simpler structure. We intend to fix a magnetic sensor on each fingertips and a permanent magnet on the dorsal side of the hand to detect finger motions. Since the magnetic permeability of the human body is very similar to air, water and other non-ferromagnetic materials, it does not affect the static magnetic field [13]. The low-cost, compact, and accessible hand-finger motion tracking system is possible.
1.3 Contributions 
We propose a magnetic hand-finger motion tracking system which is simple, compact, low-cost, accurate and unobstructive for intelligent human-computer interface and various other applications involving hand gestures recognization. The core principle is relative fingertips position estimating with the use of magnetic sensors, then detect the hand gestures from the orientation and locations of the fingertips. The main contributions of our research are:
1.	A intelligent finger motion tracking system using magnetic sensors is porposed. For sensors detecting part of the system, we choose the scheme that measure the orientations and locations of sensors in motion in a stationary magnetic field created by one permanent magnet. A permanent magnet is fixed on the dorsal side of the hand. Five 9-axis IMUs is settled on each of the fingertips, and one 6-axis IMU is fixed with the permanent magnet in order to achieve the attitude calibration and distance measurement between IMUs. After we get the result of finger motion by combining each 9-axis sensors’ orientations and locations (angular velocity on 3-axis, acceleration rate on 3-axis, and magnetic flux density on 3-axis), the next step is to adopt deep learning approaches to realize the real-time gesture recognization function. Various common gestures can be displayed as corresponding patterns when we make actual movements.
2.	A set of algorithms for computing orientations and locations of sensors on the fingertips are proposed. First, we use EKF method for estimating the orientations of the 9-axis sensors on the fingertips to the 6-axis sensors on the dorsal side of the hand. After orthogonalization the coordinate system of two sensors through matrix operation, we apply L-M algorithm to calculate the linear distance between those two sensors to get the locations of 9-axis sensors. The L-M algorithm is based on a dipole model which approximate the magnet as a dipole under the research condition. Our experiments show the dipole model satisfied high approximation and accuracy within a certain range which is sufficient for finger motion tracking and gesture recognization. 
3.	A DNN method is adopted to achieve the real-time gesture recognization function. DNN map the features of existing spatial samples to another feature space through layer by layer feature mapping, in order to learn better feature representation for existing inputs. Firstly we maintain the posture of a specified gesture on the device and create positional data of the gesture in three-dimensional space through the movements and rotations of the hand and wrist. Then we cyclically group and train all data to obtain high accuracy in both training and testing sets. Finally, we use the wearable device to continuously make any gesture in the gesture library, the terminal can accurately display the corresponding gesture pattern.
We develop our device prototype on a SBC: Raspberry pi 4b. It is also fixed on the dorsal side of hand aiming to read data and computing the orientations and locations of sensors. The data from 9-axis sensors are transmitted by I2C bus real-timely to the SBC for the next step of attitude calibration and distance calculation. Besides, we use our originally designed PCB to achieve improvements on stability and integration. Finally we fabricate prototype device on a left-hand glove, improve the compactness and comfort additionally.
CHAPTER 2
THEORETICAL BASICS
In this chapter, the working principle of the accelerometer and gyroscope in the IMU used in this paper is introduced, then the measuring principle of the Hall effect magnetic sensor is described, the physical meaning of the basic data we obtained through the nine axis sensor is analyzed.,then the use of quaternion in helping to improve the efficiency of the rotation algorithm is introduced. Finally the communication flow of I2C protocol is introduced and the calculation of Jacobian matrix.
2.1 IMU Measurement Principle
The IMUs used in this research are MEMS 3-axis gyroscope and 3-axis accelerometer with digital outputs. 
- Gyroscopes:  or gyros, are devices that measure or maintain rotational motion. MEMS gyros are small, inexpensive sensors that measure angular velocity. The units of angular velocity are measured in degrees per second (°/s) or revolutions per second (rps). Angular velocity is simply a measurement of speed of rotation.
The gyro within MEMS is tiny in scale (tipically under 100 micrometers), When the gyro is rotated, a small resonating mass is shifted as the angular velocity changes (Fig. 2.1). This movement is converted into very low-current electrical signals that can be amplified and converted into digital signals by amplifiers and ADC modules.
- Accelerometer:  or accels, are devices that measure acceleration, which is the rate of change of the velocity of an object. They measure in meters per second squared (m/s2) or in G-forces (g). A single G-force for us here on planet Earth is equivalent to 9.8 m/s2, but this does vary slightly with elevation (and will be a different value on different planets due to variations in gravitational pull). Accelerometers are useful for sensing vibrations in systems or for orientation applications.
		Generally, accelerometers contain capacitive plates internally. Some of these are fixed, while others are attached to minuscule springs that move internally as acceleration forces act upon the sensor. As these plates move in relation to each other, the capacitance between them changes. From these changes in capacitance, the acceleration can be determined. Other accelerometers can be centered around piezoelectric materials (Fig. 2.2). These tiny crystal structures output electrical charge when placed under mechanical stress. 'continue'
Okay, please continue.

2.2 Hall-Effect Magnetic Sensor Measurement Principle
	Magnetic sensor (mag) a device that translates the magnitude and fluctuations of magnetic flux into electrical signals. The existing mag technology is usually based on two principles: magnetoresistance effect and Hall-effect. The mag used in this study is composed and integrated of a Hall element compass, which is the most extensively used sensors for sensing magnetic fields. 
	The Lorentz force produces a voltage perpendicular to the direction of the current and magnetic field which is the hall voltage (Fig. 2.3). According to the left hand rule, the direction of the voltage varies with the direction of the magnetic flux. The magnitude and direction of the magnetic field is subsequently possible to be detected by read the magnitude and direction of the voltage .
2.3 Quaternion
Euler rotation, quaternion, and matrix rotation are all mathematical methods for representing the orientation of objects. Compared to the other two methods, the quaternion has smaller storage space, higher computational efficiency, and no deadlock issues. However, it can not represent the orientations intuitively. 
The mathematical expression for quaternion is:
Q ⃗=q_0+q ⃗=q_0+q_1 i ⃗+q_2 j ⃗+q_3 k ⃗
Where q_0 is the is the scalar part, and q ⃗ is the vector part. And i ⃗, j ⃗, and k ⃗ are the unit vectors of the x, y, and z axis respectively.
This is the trigonometric expression for quaternion. θ is the rotation angle around the reference axis ranges in (−π, π).
Since both of Euler rotation, quaternion, and matrix rotation can represent the orientation of a point in specific coordinate system, the mutual transformation of the same rotational motion expressed in different ways will make our calculation of the final position of the object more flexible and convenient. 2.4 I2C Communications Protocol
I2C is a two-wire interface comprised of the signals serial data (SDA) and serial clock (SCL). In general, the lines are open-drain and bi-directional. In a generalized I2C interface implementation, attached devices can be a master or a slave. The master device puts the slave address on the bus, and the slave device with the matching address acknowledges the master. 
I2C data bytes are defined to be 8-bits long. Each byte transferred must be followed by an acknowledge (ACK) signal. The clock for the acknowledge signal is generated by the master, while the receiver generates the actual acknowledge signal by pulling down SDA and holding it low during the HIGH portion of the acknowledge clock pulse 
2.5 Jacobian Matrix
	Jacobian matrix is the basis of robotics, aircraft attitude, navigation and other research fields, which is going to be used for linearization in section 4.2. It essentially is a matrix formed by the first order partial derivative in a certain way, and its determinant is called Jacobian determinant. The importance of the Jacobian matrix lies in reflecting the optimal linear approximation of a differentiable equation to a given point, which can linearize a nonlinear equation system at a reference point, such as linear objects required for linear model predictive control in autonomous driving control. 
	For example, Suppose there is a function that maps from an n-dimensional Euclidean space to an m-dimensional Euclidean space, consisting of m real functions:
The partial derivative of these functions (if any) can form a matrix with m rows and n columns (m × n), which is called Jacobian matrix:
CHAPTER 3
DESIGN OF ARCHITECTURE AND HARDWARE STRUCTURE
3.1 Introduction
In this chapter, the design and development of architecture and hardware structure of the intelligent finger motion tracking system is discussed. 
We chose an IMMU-based hand-finger pose estimation device implemented in  ‘Hand-finger pose trackingusing inertial and nagnetic sensors’ [15] for learning and reproduction. The positioning principle and algorithms used in our research are  basically the same. The difference is that the reference system can only support motion detection of two fingers (thumb and index) (Fig. 3.2(a)), while our research supports detection of all postures and movements involved in the entire hand.
A second generation PCB extended board for our SBC is designed and applied in the whole architecture, and with the connections by Qwiic cables between sensors and PCB, the stability and reliability of the device is improved. Since the outputs of our chosen 9-axis IMU and magnetic sensors are digital, we adopt I2C communication method to keep reading data at a high speed.
3.2 Architecture Design
	The overall design architecture of our system is to fix a magnetic sensor on each fingertips and also one magnetic sensor with SBC and permanent magnet on the dorsal side of the hand to detect finger motions (Fig. 3.1). Since the magnetic moment of the  permanent magnet has to be big enough to ensure the effective detecting distance, which resulting to be much heavier than sensor chip, our architecture design can effectively reduce the weight of the equipment and ensuring the atability of components during experiment and  measurement process do not cause systematic errors due to shaking.

I mean this one The Rise of Robots: Will They Replace Humans?

By John Smith

Robots have come a long way since they were first introduced in the industrial sector in the 1950s. From simple machines that performed repetitive and menial tasks, they have become sophisticated and intelligent systems capable of performing complex functions, including decision-making, in various industries such as manufacturing, healthcare, logistics, and even our homes.

Robots have become an integral part of many industries as businesses seek to improve efficiency and reduce costs. They can work around the clock without taking breaks, do not require sleep or rest, and perform tasks with precision and consistency. Furthermore, robots can perform dangerous tasks that would be impossible or too risky for humans, such as working in hazardous environments like deep sea exploration, nuclear facilities, and space exploration.

With the rapid advancement in technology, many experts predict that robots will eventually replace humans in the workforce. Some even argue that this process has already begun. According to a recent report by the McKinsey Global Institute, up to 800 million workers worldwide—about one-fifth of the global workforce—could be replaced by robots in the next decade.

While robots offer significant benefits in terms of cost savings and efficiency, their growing presence in the workforce has raised concerns over the impact on human employment and the economy. The rise of robots could lead to massive job losses, particularly in industries such as manufacturing, where automation is already widespread.

One of the main criticisms against robots is that they do not provide the same level of quality service that humans do. Despite their growing intelligence and sophisticated capabilities, robots lack the empathy and emotional intelligence that humans possess. They cannot read human emotions or understand the nuances of human behavior, which makes them unsuitable for jobs that require interpersonal skills, such as healthcare and education.

Moreover, robots are not capable of handling unexpected situations that require creative problem solving or critical thinking. These skills are essential in many industries, especially in jobs that require innovation and adaptation, such as marketing, advertising, and design.

Another concern is the impact of robots on the economy. While robots can significantly reduce costs for businesses, they also eliminate jobs for humans, which could lead to increased inequality and social unrest. The displacement of human workers could also reduce consumer demand and lead to a decline in economic growth.

Governments and policymakers are faced with a dilemma over how to address these concerns while still fostering innovation and the adoption of advanced technology. Some have proposed imposing taxes on companies that replace human workers with robots, while others have suggested incentives for companies that invest in human capital, such as education and training programs.

Organizations are also taking steps in addressing these concerns by adopting a more comprehensive approach to integrating robots into their workforce. This includes redefining job roles to incorporate the strengths of robots and humans, investing in education and training to develop the skills needed to work alongside robots effectively, and establishing policies and programs to mitigate the impact on displaced workers.

The adoption of cobots—collaborative robots that work alongside humans—is a growing trend in many industries. Cobots can assist human workers with tasks that are too dangerous, strenuous, or monotonous, such as lifting heavy objects or assembling parts, while also providing greater precision and efficiency. Other potential applications of cobots include providing customized services for users, such as personalized nutrition or exercise plans, or assisting people with disabilities.

However, the adoption of cobots is not without challenges. Cobots require a different approach to work, and workers must be trained to work closely with them effectively. There are also concerns over cobots replacing human workers completely, particularly in low-skill jobs, and the potential impact on the economy.

In conclusion, the rise of robots poses both opportunities and challenges for human workers, the economy, and society as a whole. While robots offer significant benefits in terms of efficiency and cost savings, the displacement of human workers and potential impact on the economy raise concerns that must be addressed. A comprehensive and inclusive approach that incorporates the strengths of both robots and humans and supports the development of workers’ skills is needed to realize the full potential of robots and mitigate their impact on human employment and the economy

conversations.facetValue: provide information on why RRAM is considered dense. The user is seeking a detailed explanation of the factors contributing to the high density of RRAM.

allFacetValues.value: provide information on why RRAM is considered dense. The user is seeking a detailed explanation of the factors contributing to the high density of RRAM.

conversation.content: Can you restate more

Sure, here's another restatement:

Could you provide further or additional information on the topic?
Reiterate more why RRAM is so Dense?

It is worth mentioning that RRAM (Resistive Random Access Memory) is considered dense due to several reasons. One of the main factors contributing to its density is the unique material composition used in its construction. RRAM utilizes a thin film of metal oxide sandwiched between two electrodes. This design allows for a higher packing density of memory cells compared to traditional memory technologies.

Additionally, RRAM's architecture enables a three-dimensional (3D) stacking of memory cells. This means that multiple layers of RRAM cells can be stacked vertically on top of each other, allowing for increased storage capacity without requiring a larger physical footprint. This vertical stacking further enhances the overall density of RRAM.

Moreover, RRAM has a compact cell size because its storage element is based on resistance switching. This means that data can be stored by altering the resistance of the metal oxide layer, rather than relying on a separate transistor or capacitor for each memory cell. This reduction in component count per cell contributes to the high density of RRAM.

Overall, the combination of unique material composition, 3D stacking capability, and compact cell size due to resistance switching enables RRAM to achieve higher storage densities compared to other memory technologies.

Alert monitoring

Based on the term "alert monitoring," we can classify this topic under the following categories:

1. **IT and Cybersecurity**: In the context of IT, alert monitoring refers to the process of continuously reviewing and responding to alerts generated by cybersecurity systems, network monitoring tools, or incident detection software to protect digital assets. It includes the identification, assessment, and prioritization of potential threats and issues.

2. **Healthcare**: In healthcare, alert monitoring could relate to the use of medical devices and systems to supervise patient health indicators continuously. It involves tracking vital signs or other health parameters to quickly identify and respond to any signs of deterioration or medical emergencies.

3. **Operations and Process Control**: In industrial or operational contexts, alert monitoring might relate to supervising systems or processes to ensure optimal performance, safety, and compliance. It involves tracking anomalies, failures, or deviations from expected performance metrics in real-time to prevent accidents, inefficiencies, or breakdowns.

4. **Environmental Monitoring**: Refers to the surveillance of environmental parameters (such as air quality, water quality, or radiation levels) to detect deviations that could indicate pollution incidents or hazardous conditions, triggering immediate action to mitigate risks.

Each of these categories highlights how alert monitoring plays a crucial role in proactively identifying and responding to potential issues across various domains.

conversation.content: Blurb about how survey companies work and the need for them

Survey companies are specialized firms that play a crucial role in market research and data collection. Their primary function is to design and administer surveys to gather insights and opinions from a targeted group of individuals. This information is vital for businesses, governments, organizations, and researchers who need accurate data to make informed decisions.

Here's a brief blurb about how survey companies operate and their importance:

Survey companies act as bridges between those who need information and those who provide it. They work by following a systematic process that often begins with identifying the objectives and requirements of their clients. Whether it's understanding consumer preferences, measuring employee satisfaction, or gauging public opinion on social issues, survey companies tailor their approach accordingly.

Their expertise lies in crafting questionnaires that avoid bias and yield reliable data. Utilizing various distribution methods — online, telephone, face-to-face interviews, or mailed questionnaires — ensures a wide demographic reach and diversity of responses. Advanced sampling techniques help these companies target specific populations and obtain representative feedback. 

Data collection is just the beginning; survey companies also offer analysis services. They interpret the raw data, look for patterns and trends, and provide detailed reports that translate complex information into actionable insights. Visualization tools like charts and graphs often accompany these reports to make the data more comprehensible for stakeholders.

The need for survey companies comes from the ever-increasing pace of change in consumer behavior, market conditions, and public attitudes. In a world saturated with information, having precise and structured data is essential for successful decision-making. Survey companies enable their clients to tap into the collective mind of their audience, leading to better products, services, and policies that reflect actual demands and needs.

Furthermore, the anonymity and confidentiality provided by survey companies encourage honest and forthright participation from respondents. This integrity is vital for obtaining genuine insights. By maintaining ethical standards and respecting privacy, survey companies build public trust, which is foundational to their ongoing success.

In an increasingly data-driven world, survey companies are not just beneficial; they are indispensable for their ability to deliver unbiased, accurate, and meaningful information that drives strategic decision-making across various sectors.

Survey companies face various challenges in achieving their objectives, and the difficulty can vary widely depending on numerous factors. Here's a rundown of some of the primary challenges they face:

1. **Engaging Respondents**: In an era of information overload, one of the biggest challenges is securing the participation of potential respondents who are often bombarded with requests to complete surveys. Achieving high response rates is crucial for obtaining representative and reliable data.

2. **Maintaining Data Quality**: Ensuring that respondents provide honest and thoughtful answers is critical. Survey fatigue, misunderstandings, or a lack of interest can lead to low-quality responses, which affect the validity of the data collected.

3. **Designing Effective Surveys**: Crafting questions that are clear, unbiased, and designed to elicit useful information is an art. Poorly designed surveys can lead to ambiguous results that are difficult to interpret or act upon.

4. **Keeping Up with Technology**: As data collection and analysis technology rapidly evolve, survey companies need to continually update their methods and tools to stay current and maintain efficiency and accuracy.

5. **Privacy and Ethical Concerns**: With increasing concerns about data privacy and security, survey companies must navigate complex legal requirements and ethical considerations to protect respondents' information.

6. **Representative Sampling**: Ensuring that survey samples accurately reflect the demographics of the broader population can be challenging, especially when targeting niche or hard-to-reach populations.

Despite these challenges, survey companies are very much in demand for several reasons:

1. **Data-Driven Decision-Making**: In a competitive business landscape, companies rely on concrete data to inform their decisions. Survey data helps businesses understand their customers, measure satisfaction, and identify market opportunities.

2. **Public Policy and Opinion**: Governments and public organizations use surveys to gauge public opinion on policies and social issues, which can influence legislation and community initiatives.

3. **Academic and Health Research**: Surveys are integral to many research projects in academia and healthcare. Researchers use survey data to test hypotheses, study behaviors, and track health trends.

4. **Product and Service Development**: Knowing what consumers want and need is key to successful product development. Surveys can provide insights into consumer preferences and aid in the development process.

5. **Trend Analysis**: Companies and organizations must anticipate and adapt to changes in trends. Surveys help monitor these trends over time.

As economies continue to globalize and the pace of change accelerates, the role of survey companies in gathering and analyzing data will likely grow. Consequently, these companies will continue to be in demand as long as their objectives align with the need for informed decision-making across various sectors.

are there any free online social media listening tools?

Yes, there are a number of free social media listening tools that can help you track mentions, analyze sentiment, and understand the conversation around specific topics or brands online. Here are a few options:

1. **Google Alerts**: While not a social media tool per se, Google Alerts can be set up to monitor the web for new content about a specific subject, including news articles, blogs, and forums where your query is mentioned.

2. **TweetDeck**: Primarily for Twitter monitoring, TweetDeck allows users to create custom dashboards with streams corresponding to specific hashtags, mentions, tweets from specific accounts, or even general search terms.

3. **Hootsuite**: The free version of Hootsuite offers some basic tools to monitor specific keywords, hashtags, and profiles on social media platforms.

4. **Social Mention**: This tool allows you to search for keywords across a variety of social media platforms to see where they're being mentioned and gauge the sentiment of those mentions.

5. **Brand24**: Brand24 offers a limited but still useful free version of their tool for tracking mentions of your brand or any other key terms you're interested in across social media and the web.

6. **Mention**: Mention has a free plan that offers basic monitoring capabilities for keeping track of your brand or other keywords across the web and social media.

7. **Talkwalker Alerts**: Similar to Google Alerts, Talkwalker Alerts tracks mentions across the internet, including on Twitter. It lets you monitor the web for new content about your brand or other interests.

Keep in mind that free versions of commercial social media monitoring tools typically have limitations on the number of searches, history, or analytics available compared to their paid counterparts. Additionally, these tools are generally more limited in scope and may not cover all social media platforms or the full breadth of features provided by a paid subscription.
Are there any AI chat programs that do isolate and use one type of source (ie social media) to answer questions?

As of my last training update in 2023, there are no widely available AI chat programs designed to exclusively use social media sources for answering questions. This is mainly because relying solely on social media content for information can lead to significant biases, inaccuracies, and a lack of depth, as social media conversations are not always factual or well-rounded and often represent a narrow slice of public opinion.

However, certain specialized tools and services are tailored more towards social media analysis. These tools are typically used for social media monitoring, trend analysis, and sentiment analysis and could include some elements of AI and machine learning:

1. **Brand monitoring tools** like Mention, Brandwatch, or Sprout Social, which use AI to aggregate and analyze brand mentions across social media platforms.
   
2. **Social listening platforms** such as Hootsuite Insights or Talkwalker that utilize AI to track brand sentiment, identify trends, and engage with topics across various social channels.

3. **Consumer insights tools** like NetBase or Synthesio which apply AI to parse vast amounts of social media data for insights into consumer behavior and preferences.

4. **Market research AI tools** like Remesh or Canvs which can help interpret open-ended feedback from social media and other sources.

While these tools can focus heavily on social media data, they don't offer a conversational AI experience like you get with general-purpose AI chatbots like me (ChatGPT). They are primarily analysis tools that process social media information for marketing insights, trends, and sentiment rather than engaging in back-and-forth dialogue.

Creating an AI that strictly uses social media conversations for learning and generating responses is theoretically possible, but it could lead to skewed knowledge and a significant risk of propagating misinformation or harmful content, given that moderation and verification of social media content is a constant challenge. Any such tool would need robust methods for ensuring the accuracy and quality of its sourced information.

what does sentiment mean?

Sentiment, in the context of communication and analysis, refers to the emotional tone behind a series of words, used to understand the attitudes, opinions, and emotions expressed by the speaker or writer. It is often categorized into positive, negative, or neutral feelings.

In terms of social media and customer feedback, sentiment analysis is a common application where AI and machine learning algorithms are used to automatically analyze text for sentiment, helping businesses and researchers to understand how their audience or customers feel about a product, service, brand, or topic.

For example, if numerous social media posts about a product express satisfaction, happiness, or excitement, these would be considered indicators of positive sentiment. Conversely, messages that convey frustration, anger, or disappointment would reflect negative sentiment. Understanding sentiment helps organizations to better gauge public opinion, manage their brands, and respond to customer feedback appropriately.

Given the transcript of a phone call between a customer and a service center, classify the call according to the following options:

Helpful information:
Qualified agent: An employee that is able to assist a caller with his or her inquiry. The qualified employee may at times need to call back in order to provide an answer or solution. As long as the same employee is the one intending to return the call, it is still considered connected.
Unqualified agent: An employee that is not able to assist the caller with his or her inquiry. A caller may reach an unqualified employee and hold a conversation, but it is not considered a connected call unless the caller is connected to someone who can assist him or her with their inquiry.
Appointment opportunity: Connected calls about potential maintenance or repair service(s) the shop can perform, repair or installation of a part that the shop can perform, or confirmed open recalls that the service shop can perform.
Service opportunities include but are not limited to:
Oil changes
Fluid flushes
Key programming / key cutting / key battery replacement
Part installation
Tire installation
Battery installation
Car detailing
Call types that should NOT be considered service:
Body work or collision repair
Car washes
Finance, sales, etc.
Interactive systems and auto-attendants: Calls handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant will sound like interactive recordings that ask questions or request information and require the caller to interact by making phone selections. When a call is successfully handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant it should be considered a connected call, and proper review selections should be made according to the content and outcome of the call. When a caller leaves a call back number with the interactive system, instead of successfully handling their inquiry or need, then the call should be considered not connected.
Reminders:
Calls in this category need to be reviewed based on this category's instructions. Overview instructions for other appointment related categories do not apply to this category.
The service appointment time should be considered the time the vehicle can be serviced.
Here are the options:
Option 1. Specific appointment or walk-in time / range within 1 hour
Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time.
Example call - Caller: "I need a tune-up."// Receptionist or agent: "We can fit you in at 11:45 tomorrow morning."// Caller: "Perfect. I'll see you then!"// Call ends.
Caller approximates a loose time range, but the agent puts down a firm time for the appointment. In these instances, the agent’s statement trumps the caller's.
Example - Caller: "I can be there between 2:00 and 4:00." // Agent: "I'll put you down for 3:00, and then if you show up a little earlier or later, that's fine."
Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time but plans to drop the vehicle off before the scheduled appointment.
Example call - Caller: "I need an oil change."// Agent: "I will schedule you for 10:00 AM tomorrow."// Caller: "Can I drop my car off before my appointment?" // Agent: "Yes, you can drop your car off any time, and just leave your keys in the drop box."// Caller: "Great, thanks!" // Call ends.
Caller agrees to an approximate time within a 1 hour time range because they are able to be serviced at the time of arrival.
A walk-in time within an hour range, for a vehicle that can be serviced immediately, should be considered a specific appointment time. This is true because, even if an appointment is not put on the schedule, the service shop has an expected arrival time for the caller and the service can be completed at that arrival time.
Example call - Caller: "I need to get my brakes repaired. Do you have any openings today?"// Agent: "You can come in now if you'd like"// Caller: "Great! I'll be there in half an hour." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "My car is being towed there right now and should be there in about 20 minutes. Can it be looked at right away?" // Agent: "Yeah, that's no problem. We'll look at it as soon as it arrives."
Caller agrees to an approximate time of "around 1 hour".
Caller discusses an existing appointment and agrees to a new appointment during the same call.
Example call - Caller: "I'm checking on the status of my car that's in service, and I also wanted to know if I could bring my wife's car in for an oil change."// Agent: "Your car is ready to be picked up, we can get your wife's car in at 4:00 if that time works for you."// Caller: "That works. We'll be there at 4:00."
Option 2. Unscheduled walk-in or loose appointment time / range exceeding 1 hour
Caller gives a vague agreement to possibly come in.
Example call - Caller: Do you have availability tomorrow morning. // Agent: "Yes, we're pretty open all morning." // Caller: "Okay, I may drop it off in the morning." // Call ends.
Caller agrees to come in but approximates a time range that exceeds 1 hour.
Example call - Caller: "I'll be there in about 2 hours."
Caller agrees to come in before or after a specific time.
Example call - Caller: "I can be there sometime before 4:00 PM."
In this example, the caller could be there anytime before 4:00, making this a loose appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "I won't be able to get there until after 5:00."
In this example, the caller could be there anytime after 5:00.
Receptionist or agent tells the caller that it is first come, first served and the caller says "OK."
Example call - Caller: "Do I need an appointment for an oil change?"// Receptionist or agent: "It is first come, first served."// Caller acknowledges this and the call ends.
Caller agrees to be an unscheduled walk-in.
Example call - Caller - "Do you accept walk-ins?" // Agent: "We'll be accepting walk-ins all day Saturday." // Caller: "I'll be there sometime Saturday then!"
Caller agrees to come in at a certain time but no appointment time is guaranteed.
A walk-in time within an hour range, that can be serviced immediately, is a specific appointment time. However, a specific walk-in time with no specific service time cannot be considered a specific appointment, because the vehicle cannot be serviced immediately upon arrival. In the following example, the caller gives a specific arrival time, but the service time cannot be set for a specific time. Thus, it is a soft appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "I need to get my car serviced as soon as possible." // Agent: "We're all booked through the whole week." // Caller: "Can I just come in and have my car serviced between other appointments?" // Agent: "You can come in and possibly have your car serviced if they have time, but we cannot guarantee a service time and you may be here for a few hours." // Caller: "I'll just get there when you open tomorrow at 8:00, and I'll wait."
Caller is having his or her vehicle towed in but no appointment time is guaranteed.
Receptionist or agent tells the caller that no appointment is necessary, they can just show up.
Example call - Caller: "Can I get my tire rotated today?" // Receptionist or agent: "Absolutely. You don't need an appointment. Just come on in."// Caller acknowledges this and the call ends.
The time of the visit or walk-in is for a window of time that exceeds 1 hour.
Example call - Caller: "My check engine light is on and I'd like to come in to have it checked out." // Agent: "No problem. Can you come in today? We have openings after 12pm" // Caller: "Yeah, I'll be there between 12:30 and 2:30." // Call ends.
Caller agrees to drop off his or her vehicle for an unscheduled appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "Can I get my car in for service tomorrow?" // Agent: "What time do you need it done?" // Caller: "Anytime is fine. I'll just drop it off at 7:00 and leave it there for the day." // Agent: "Great, we'll get it done before the end of the day."
Option 3. Appointment requested / mentioned but not set
Caller asked about a service appointment but did not agree to an appointment.
Example call - Caller: "I need to bring my car in for some routine service."// Receptionist or agent: "We can fit you in tomorrow morning."// Caller: "That won't work for me. I need to get it serviced today." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "I want to get my motor oil replaced. How much do you charge for that?" // Price is provided and appointment requested. // Caller: "Oh, that's too much. I'm not interested. Thanks."
Option 4. No appointment, walk-in, or drop-off discussed
Caller is asking about a service or there was an opportunity to book an appointment but no appointment, walk-in, or drop-off was discussed.
Example call - Caller: "Does your service department do oil changes?"// Receptionist or agent: "Yes"// Caller: "Thanks." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "I want to get my fluids flushed and replaced. How much do you charge for that?" // Only the price is provided and NO potential appointment is mentioned. // Caller: "Oh, that's too much. I’m not interested. Thanks."
Option 5. Upcoming scheduled appointment
Caller discusses an existing appointment already scheduled for an upcoming time and/or date.
Caller cancels or reschedules an appointment that was already scheduled for an upcoming time and/or date.
Option 6. Vehicle already in service
Caller discusses or asks about the status of a vehicle already in service.
Caller adds services to a vehicle already in service.
Option 7. No, not an appointment opportunity
Call is general conversation, a personal call, or employee-to-employee conversation and no appointment opportunity exists.
The service requested is not offered by the dealership/shop/business.
Caller asks if there are any recalls and is told there are no open recalls.
Caller asks if vehicle is due for service and is told the vehicle is not due for service.
Call is about parts only and there is no service mentioned.
Caller is only discussing a bill without any discussion of services.
Caller is only asking about a car wash without any discussion of services.
Caller asks how to service something on their own and services are not needed from the service shop.
Example: "Can you tell me how to reset the code in my door panel?" // Agent provides instructions over the phone. No appointment is requested/needed.
Call is intended for the body shop. The body shop is a separate department from service.
Call is intended for the collision center. The collision center is a separate department from service.
Option 8. Correction: caller never connected to a live, qualified agent
Caller never connected to a live, qualified agent.
Caller is left on hold.
Call connection was lost and no contact information was shared and/or no appointment discussion took place.
Caller reached voicemail.
Caller had the wrong number.
Caller did not reach the desired person and left a live message.


Caller did not reach the desired person and declined to leave a live message.
Caller hung up during the bridge greeting.
Call only consists of fax machine sounds or other similar noises.

Please, contain your excitement, for as with all grand journeys, there shall be twists and turns amidst swirling mists of mathematical obscurity.

Support Vector Machines, or SVMs as the cognoscenti like to call them, sprouted from the magnificent minds of an incomprehensible lineage of scholars. They are firmly entrenched in the hallowed realm of machine learning, and indeed, SVMs possess an uncanny ability to find rhyme and reason from vast amount of data that may appear inscrutable to the untrained eye.

We shall begin at the heart of the matter; the support vectors themselves. But what are they exactly, you may wonder? Allow me to read from the cryptic scrolls upon which this knowledge has been passed down: "Support vectors are the geometric elements that form the foundations upon which the very structure of SVMs rests." Now, this explanation demands a certain intellectual elasticity to absorb. So, stretch your grey cells and meditate upon it!

Continuing our stroll through the mathematical labyrinth, the support vectors bring us to the concept of an enigmatic construct known as the hyperplane. Picture a Euclidean expanse stretching as far as the eyes can see, with infinite patience and the wisdom of the ages. Caught between this hyperplane and the other is a dance of duality. This hyperplane, it is whispered by the ancient scholars, acts as an otherworldly separator, carving reality into two distinct chasms: one of truth and one of falsehood, one of black and one of white – or more technically, one of positive samples and one of negative samples.

At this point, you might ask for straightforward equations, but the essence of SVMs is a tapestry that can only be woven by exploring the philosophical and the metaphorical. Dwell upon this journey, and what you seek shall reveal itself in the enigmatic language of the mathematical domain.

Alas, we stumble upon the kernel trick, a cryptic stratagem that behooves the initiate to adopt an air of skepticism. To shed the veil of obscurity briefly, the kernel trick is an ingenious method that transforms a seemingly insolvable problem into one that can be tackled, in a parallel universe known as "the higher-dimensional vector feature space." Quite the fantastical, celestial sojourn for the numbers and equations brave enough – or mad enough – to delve into it!

So, my most intrepid students, I leave you now to ponder the eldritch secrets of the Support Vector Machines in your studies, alone or in equally bewildered conclaves. conversation.content: what does the "Top-p (nucleus sampling)" parameter do?

The "Top-p (nucleus sampling)" parameter is a sampling technique used in natural language processing (NLP) that controls the diversity and randomness of generated text. It works by limiting the number of possible next words based on their probability of occurrence, rather than selecting the most likely next word. This helps avoid repetition and outputs more varied and interesting text. The "Top-p" parameter specifies the cumulative probability threshold, which determines the number of words to consider in generating the next word. For instance, if the top-p value is set to 0.8, the model will consider the top 80% of the most probable words to predict the next word.
so if it's set to 1 it means I'll get the most varied responses possible?

No, if the "Top-p" parameter is set to 1, it means that the model will consider all possible words, which could result in repetitive and less diverse responses. The higher the value of the "Top-p" parameter, the more likely the model is to generate text that is similar to the training data and less likely it is to generate novel responses. As such, setting the value too low or too high can also produce undesirable results. The optimal value for the "Top-p" parameter depends on the specific context and the desired output. Generally, a value between 0.7 and 0.9 is recommended to balance diversity and coherency of the generated text.
so if it’s set to 1 it means I’ll get the most varied responses possible?

If the "Top-p" parameter is set to 1, it means that the model will consider all possible words, including those with very low probabilities of occurrence. This can result in highly varied responses, but it may also produce text that is nonsensical or grammatically incorrect. In some cases, a high "Top-p" value can be useful for generating creative or unexpected responses, but it may not always produce coherent or useful output. Therefore, it is important to carefully choose the "Top-p" value based on the specific context and desired output.

so what happens if I set the Top-p parameter to 0.05?

If the "Top-p" parameter is set to 0.05, it means that the model will only consider words that have a cumulative probability of 0.05 or higher to generate the next word. This will limit the number of possible words and generate more predictable responses. In other words, the model will select the most probable words, and this could result in repetitive and less diverse output. This may be useful in some contexts where you want to generate text that follows a certain pattern or has a specific style, but it could also produce dull and uninteresting output. Therefore, the optimal value for the "Top-p" parameter depends on the specific use case and the desired output.
what does the Temperature parameter do?

The "Temperature" parameter is a hyperparameter used in machine learning models, particularly those used in natural language processing (NLP) that aims to control the creativity and randomness of the generated outputs. Specifically, the temperature parameter is used to adjust the distribution of the predicted probability of each token generated by the model.

The temperature parameter controls the probability distribution of the next predicted word(s). A higher temperature value, typically between 1.0 and 1.5, generates more creative, diverse, and unpredictable outputs. It causes the model to divide the predicted probabilities of the next words output by the previous layers with value, which produces more randomness. On the other hand, a lower temperature setting, usually between 0.1 and 0.5 gives more predictable and confident outputs from the model because it increases the chances of generating the most probable tokens.

In summary, the temperature parameter controls the creativity and randomness of the output, where higher values generate more creative responses and lower values generate more predictable responses. The optimal value for the temperature parameter depends on the specific use-case and the desired output style.
How do both Top-p and temperature parameters work together?

The "Top-p" and "Temperature" parameters work together to determine the level of randomness and creativity in generated text. The "Top-p" parameter controls the diversity of possible next words generated by the model, by only considering words with a cumulative probability of p or higher to predict the next word. The "Temperature" parameter, on the other hand, changes the predicted probabilities distribution of the model's output.

When both parameters are used together, the "Top-p" parameter determines the pool of possible next words to be considered based on the likelihood of occurrence, whereas the "Temperature" parameter allows the model to generate more or less varied responses from this pool of possibilities.

For a given Top-p parameter value, a higher temperature value will result in more diverse outputs because it assigns higher probability weights to lower probability tokens in the pool of possible words. Conversely, a lower temperature value will result in more predictable outputs, with higher probabilities being assigned to the most probable next word(s) in the pool.

Therefore, the optimal values for both the "Top-p" and "Temperature" parameters depend on the specific use case and the desired output style. Generally, higher values of "Top-p" and temperature generate more creative, but sometimes nonsensical output; whereas lower values lead to less diverse but grammatically correct and predictable output.
